THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

MARCH 5, 1903.

No. 10.

COMMEMORATION DAY CELEBRATION.
OHNS HOPKINS celebrated the twenty-seventh anniversary of her foundation on Monday, February 23, by the customary commemoration exercises
with which her birthdays have been regularly observed in the past. On
several recent occasions these exercises have been marked by announcements
of such importance as to excite interest wherever men are who concern themselves with the progress of American education. First came the University's •
application for aid from the State of Maryland; then various statements concerning the movements set going to restore her to the stabler position of the
fore-time, movements gradually centering in that final one by which the endowment fund of $1,000,000 was completed last summer, and last of all, the opening
of "The Promised Land" on upper Charles street. The optimists who
expected President Remsen to acknowledge the gift of funds ample to cover the
Homewood acres with stately buildings in which the great fame of Hopkins
shall grow greater, as a proper culmination to the double quick of earlier events,
were not fully gratified. President Remsen's own remarks indicated that he
himself knew of many such.
"A gentleman stopped me on .the street the other day and declared he
would^be sorely disappointed unless I announced that we have enough money
in hand to build at. Homewood," he said. "I could only smile then, and I can
do nothing better now."
"If you ask,'what, then are you going to do with Homewood?' I should
reply, that we shall for the present study it—learn how it will best serve our
Purpose, and none but the ,best advice will suit us. You know already that
the president of our Board, Mr. R. Brent Keyser, has provided funds to enable
us to secure expert advice. I may also tell you that the trustees, as many as
can leave, will go this spring upon a tour of observation to learn what other
universities can teach us for the development of the Homewood land. They
will visit Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Columbia, Cornell, Virginia and other
places, too, perhaps."
The memory of Henry A. Rowland, whose researches in physics, contributing a great measure to the renown of Johns Hopkins, will endure of their
own merit, is assured of fuller perpetuation in the University itself by a gift •
announced at the exercises. A student of the late Professor Rowland has
offered to buy a complete library covering the field of spectroscopy, which was
..

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

one of the special branches of science which Dr. Rowland cultivated for many
years with great success. "The Rowland Memorial Library of Spectroscopy"
will he the name of the new collection, and Mrs. Rowland has contributed to it
all of the Professor's own books on that subject.
By the gift of $25,000 from Dr. and Mrs. Christian H. Herter, of New York,
the University will be able to invite some eminent professor of that branch of
science to lecture in Baltimore each year hereafter.
The commemoration exercises were those which are generally familiar to
all who have ever been students at Johns Hopkins. The Academic procession,
this year under the Chief Marshalship of Dr. Harry L Wilson, entered the
auditorium to a march rendered by an orchestra under the direction of Prof. W.
Edward Heimendahl of the Peabody Conservatory. President Remsen headed
the line in company with the orator of the day, President Edwin A. Alderman,
of Tulane University, President Emeritus D. C. Gilman following with the
chaplain, Dr. Arthur Chilton Powell. The guests and several academic bodies
coming after in the usual order.
The President, the President Emeritus, and the Orator, occupied the center
of the stage, Dr. Remsen seated in the President Chair presented two years ago
by the Harvard Club of Maryland.
In introducing the speaker of the day, President Remsen said: "A year
ago a company in Music Hall, at a banquet memorable in the annals of Johns
Hopkins, weary, perhaps, with the lapse of hours, suddenly woke up. It was
near midnight, but an electric shock had passed—a speech generated it. It
could not last long, however, because the next day was Sunday. When we
came to prepare for this occasion it occurred to us that we could do no better
than invite the man who made that speech a year ago to continue it here this
morning. It gives me great pleasure, accordingly, to present to you President
Alderman of Tulane University, New Orleans"
President Alderman's address was devoted for the most part to a retrospective and prospective view of the South. In the most glowing manner he
spoke of the splendid and noble attributes of the old South, not, however,
neglecting to acknowledge those defects and vices which have disappeared
before the forces of modern civilization. Referring to the present time, Dr.
Alderman told of the great change that has now progressed so far, the passing
of the traditional and agricultural South into the active, modern industrial community. Believing that the South has before it a great future, along with the
rest of the nation, President Alderman feels that the great need of the South is
the placing of its educational system upon an equal footing with that which
exists in the most advanced and prosperous parts of the land.
The degree of Doctor of Philosophy was conferred upon Mr. Frederick
Hutton Getman, University of Virginia; Mr. Benjamin Leroy Miller, A. B.,
University of Kansas, 1897; Mr. Henry Nevi11 Sanders, A. B., Trinity University, Toronto, 1894, and Mr. Daniel Naylor Shoemaker, S. B., Earlham College, 1895.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

As previously noted in THrt NEWS-LETTER, Dr. Getman will enter next
September upon a physical chemical investigation under a recent grant from
the Carnegie Institute.
The growing interest in the exercises caused such a demand for tickets that
many persons were unable to obtain them and even a number of those holding
tickets were unable to gain admittance into the assembly room. Referring to
the necessity of having a larger auditorium in which to hold the Commemo
ration Day exercises, Dr. Remsen said: "I do not know whether or not this
hall will serve us another year for our present purposes. There are too many
in it at this moment; but notwithstanding this we have been obliged to turn
away a great many of those we should like to see here. This could not be
avoided, but we will try to devise means by which we may have all our friends
with us on future occasions of this sort."

THE ALUMNI BANQUET.

t

H E annual banquet of the Alumni Association held at the Carrollton Hotel
on the night of the 23rd, made a fitting close for the day's celebration.
At a short business meeting before the banquet, the gentlemen who had
been nominated by the Executive Committee, as announced in the last issue of
the “liftws-LETTHR," were elected to hold office for the ensuing year. The
company then proceeded to the banquet hall, where an excellent dinner was
thoroughly enjoyed. At the conclusion, toast-master Dr. W. T. Sedgwick, the
retiring president of the association, made a short address of welcome to the
Alumni, in which he dwelt strongly on the national character of the University,
which he said was the pioneer in the work of nationalizing the educational field
of the country. He also spoke of the vast amount of useful work which the
University could do if only the requisite funds were provided. Those who responded to toasts were:—
Dr. Gilman. introduced as the "Master of Johns Hopkins," who
spoke of the national influence exerted by the Univetsity, and mentioned many
of its graduates who have attained distinction in the various paths of life, es-,
pecially in the province of higher education.
President Remsen, who emphasized the fact that the true purpose of a university was to train men for scientific investigation. He said that, as the de
mand for investigators in this country far exceeded the supply, he believed such
institutions as the Carnegie and Rockefellet Institutes to be detrimental; for
they tend to draw away from the universities men fitted to train these investigators
Dr. Alderman, who depicted the noble grander of the "scholar-patriot."
Mr. Theodore Marburg, who spoke on behalf of the trustees.
Professor H. H. Donaldson, Ph. D., 1885, dean of graduate school of the
University of Chicago.
.

UNIVERSITY NOTES.

HE School Board has asked President Remsen to select some one to chose
140 names of Marylatv'ers which may be appropriately used to designate
the public schools of the city, and has appropriated the sum of $100 as
compensation.

t

"The Capacity of the Porto Ricans for Citizenship" was the subject of a
lecture delivered by Dr. J. W. Hollander before the members of the "Lend-aHand Club," on February 23.
At the twenty-first anniversary of the founding of the Woman's Medical
College, on February 21, Dr. Henry M. Hurd delivered an address on "The
Study of Medicine."
Dr. Wm. H. Howell was the guest of honor at the annual reunion and dinner of the New England Alumni Association held in Boston on the night of
February 21.
Dr. Paul Shorey, professor of Greek Literature at the University of Chicago,
will lecture upon "Realism and Idealism in Greek Literature" in McCoy Hall
on the evening of March 18. The lecture will be delivered under the auspices
of the Baltimore Society of the Archaeological Institute of America.
At a meeting of the alumni and students of the Southern Home School held
in the Franklin Street Presbyterian Church, on February 26, it was decided, if
$5,000 could be raised, to establish a lectureship at the University as a fitting
memorial to Mrs. Jane M. Cary, who died on January 22, and who was the
founder of the school, and for many years its principal.
"The Tale of Gyges and the King of Lydia" by Dr. Kirby F. Smith which
was published in The. American Journal of Philology, Vol. xxiii, No 3, has
been reprinted in a neat pamphlet.
Bartgis McGlone, who, since receiving his A. B. last June, had been a
graduate student in biology has been appointed instructor of biology at Illinois
Wesleyan College.
• Dr. Olner L. Fassig delivered a lecture on "Weather Forecasting, Ancient
and Modern" before the members of the Philosophical Society of the Woman's
College on February 19. The lecture was illustrated with charts and designs.
The New York Alumni Association held its annual banquet on the night
of February 28. Dean Griffin was the guest of honor, and delivered the principal address. Dr. J. M. Vincent, who was also in attendance, made a short
speech
The name of Professor Joseph S. Ames appears in a committee memoralizing Father Angelo Secchi, S. J., on the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary
of the death of the great Jesuit astronomer and physicist. Dr. Ames lately received from Rome a fine photo engraving of Secchi.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

The director of the Physical Labatory recently requested the co-operation
of other labatories, observatories, and investigators in the completion and
maintenance Cif the "Rowland Memorial Library of Spectroscopy," the founda
tion of which was announced on Commemoration Day. In reply he has re
ceived several hundred promises of assistance, many of them accompanied by
valuable books and reprints.
UNDERGRADUATE NOTES.
CCORDING to a report about the University the increased interest in
athletics and debating that several Seniors have recently shown is due to
their desire to be voted the most versatile man in the class.

4

•1

On the night of Monday, February 23, the Senior Class held its annual
banquet at the St. James Hotel. This year's gathering was the occasion of
even a more glorious time than the Junior banquet of last year. Toastmaster
H. W. Plaggetneyer called upon Harry K. Tootle, Wm. S. Bird and W. M.
Hunley, who responded in their most happy vein.
Dr J. M. Vincent is delivering a series of illustrated lectures on "Mediae,ral
Architecture," before the members of the major history class.
Mr. Howard Matthai has been appointed chairman of the Committee ot
Arrangements for the inter-class debate. The date of the inter-collegiate debate
has not been definitely announced, but it will not occur until after Easter.
R. Gordon Dulany was in New York on last Saturday where he represented
the University at the annual meeting of the I. C. A. A. A. A.
ALUMNI NOTES.
Dr. N. A. Kent, who had been assistant in the Yerkes Observatory since
receiving his doctor's degree two years ago, has resigned, in order to accept the
professorship of physic in Wabash College, Ind. Professor Kent will visit
friends in this city next week.
A text-book of "Practical Physics for Students of Science and Engineering," in four volumes, has just been published by Dr. Erwin S. Ferry, of
Purdue University. Professor Ferry at one time held a fellowship at the
University.

on Wednesday, March 11

ECENTLY a great scare was given the men who make the barber shop their
official headquarters when not attending classes. Owing to an order
which emanated from some unknown source all the chairs were removed
from the room. Fortunately for those tired mortals who settle all the great
questions of the day, while seated in the chairs which have been provided for
Walter's patrons, on the following day the chairs were returned, and the dove
of peace settled once more above the doorway. Had the chairs not been returned, although the NEWS.LETTER would have objected, yet it would have
been honest enough to acknowledge that there was wisdom in the order which
emanated from the aforesaid unseen source. We cannot deny that the barber
shop is most conducive to that most catching of college diseases—loafing. We
cannot deny that as a result of the above mentioned disease the place at times
does not present the most tidy appearance. We cannot deny that at times the
atmosphere is dense with .the smoke of the vile weed. We cannot deny that
Walter some times gets so interested in a story or a colloquy that he inadvertently chips off a corner of the face of some trusting, unwary patron. In all
this there is danger. But on the other hand there is one thing which, to our
mind, overbalances these drawbacks and turns the scales in favor of providing
seats for those men who prefer idleness to industry, and the freedom of a barber
shop debate to the august solemnness of the house or the senate. It is this

g

THE NEWS LETTER.

7

College life at best is but for a shOrt season. Soon the men who now are engaged
in looking at life from what we may call a theoretical view point will be looking
at the same problem from its practical side, and in mmory they will live over
again their college days They will not think of the days spent in the laboratory as much EIS they will of the days spent in chasing the pigskin over the
field, they will not think of the dry lectures as much as the wet banquets, and
they will not think of the papers they read in class as much as they will of the
hours stolen from study to spend in the midst of that bohemian organization
known as the Fernandig Club. In a word, it is not the memory of the duh
faithfully done which brings the same pleasure in after years as the mcmory of
those moments of relaxation when we .pause in the harness to take breath before continuing the steady pull up the hill. We have no historic "fence" upon
which the upper classmen may perch, we have no historic steps upon which the
men may sing college ballads, we have nothing but Walter's barbershop. So
let us try and preserve that intact. And may every man, when his day comes
to leave, carry away with him no darker view of college life than that he obtains in Walter's tonsorial parlor!
N an article in the last issue of the NEWS—LETTER under the heading of
"Base Ball for 1903," it was stated that the "statement may now be accepted as authoritative that Hopkins will have a base ball team this
season." This was erroneous, and the NEWS LETTER regrets that it was given
to the public in a manner which seemed to vouch for the authenticity of the report. As long ago as the holidays the Athletic Board declared that there
would be no representative team this season. It is true that a team composed
of Hopkins men will play during the season; but they have not the sanction ot
the Athletic Board, nor are they at liberty to use Hopkins' name as has been
done in several newspaper articles and in the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER.
The base ball enthusiasts are in the main men from the Medical School, and if
the team takes the field as an independent, self-supporting organization it might
well be called the Johns Hopkins Medical School Base Ball Team, as at Yale
there is a Yale Law School Base Ball Team. This would relieve the men from
being under the authority and discipline of the Athletic Association. Although
the team will be composed of University men it must be understood that the
Athletic Association offers no guarantee for the fulfillment of their pledges

j

WING to the inclement weather the annual concert by the Musical Clubs
at Lehmann's Hall was not as largely attended as it would have been
under more favorable conditions, But the management are well content
with the financial result of the concert. From an artistic point of view the concert
was a veritable triumph. The leaders showed excellent discrimination in their
selection of pieces,•and the men sang and played with that hearty good will
which characterizes college men when they have an apprecia'ive audience.
The Easter trip is not far distant, and the men are certain of an enthusiastic reception wherever they appear if they keep up to the high mark set by
their Baltimore performance.

PROSPECTS FOR THE COMING DEBATE.
S the time draws nearer for the inter-class debate which will probably he
held on March 2 1 st, interest on the part of those who are contesting for
the various places on the teams is perceptibly increasing. Both Juniors
and Seniors are buckling down to work. and are sifting out all the material they
can find on the subject of the debate. Practice is held every day under the
direction of Dr. Lee and Mr. Burgess of the Baltimore School of Oratory, at
which times the echoes of McCoy Hall are rudely awakened by the impassioned
eloquence of aspiring orators. Indeed, every indication seems to show that
both sides will put up a stiff fight on the.night of the twenty-first.
The cbntest has, however, narrowed down to six men on each side from
which the speakers and alternates of the two teams will be chosen.
For the Seniors, these are Plaggemeyer, Blum, Strayer, Tootle, Addison,
Glocker.
For the Juniors, they are Licking, Humrichouse, Foster, Rosenheim,
Stollenwerck, Crozier.
It has also been decided to have adviEers as in former years. The advisers
for the Seniors will probably be Custis, Ammen, Parsons, and Hopper. Those
for the Juniors wiil be chosen from Loyd, Emig, Geiger, Wallis, and Opie
The Freshmen who will contest on the night of the debate for the medal
offered by Dr. Lee, will be selected from Strauglin, Boyce, Ziegler and Goldman.
After the inter-class contest, comes the debate with North Carolina. The
southern university has, so report says, put us down as one of their regular
annular scalps, but we want to disappoint them, and wipe out the defeat of
last year by carrying victory into the heart of the Carolinas. To do this, every
man must come out and work. It is probable that the speakers who will represent Hopkins will be selected from the inter-class debating teams, but every
undergraduate is eligible, and, if he only makes manifest his latent ability, will
receive due consideration. But those who do not possess the gift of eloquence
are not absolved. Valuable assistance can be rendered by a squad of enthusiastic workers who will help to write speeches,, run down material, and, above
all, criticise the arguments of the speakers, instead of waiting, as usual, for
defeat to he announced before letting forth a stored.up flood of criticism.

COLLEGE TAILOR PRIZES WON BY HOPKINS MEN.
HE February number of the College Tailor, which, we recall, is being Published by Lemmert, should be of especial interest to Hopkins men, not
only because it is dedicated to the University of North Carolina with
whom we have been on the most intimate terms, but because both the prize
stories therein were written by Hopkins men. In the first issue of the College
Tailor, prizes were offered for the best football and hunting stories. These
were captured by Mr. Walter B. Carver, leader of the Hopkins Glee Club, and
Mr. Charles W. Kolb, who also studied at Hopkins.

t

9

THE-NEWS-LETTER.

Besides the prize stories, the present issue contains several very clear half
tone cuts of the buildings at the University of North Carolina, a picture of
President F. P. Venable and a general article on the growth of the university
since its foundation 108 years ago.
The College Tailor is being edited by a clever young newspaper man of
Baltimore, who is far-sighted enough to make each issue of particular interest
to college men without sacrificing too much the interests of Lemmert, the
promoter.
The idea is a novel and effective one for reaching the students at the dif'Trent institutions and promises to accomplish its purpose.

OUR BARBER SHOP CHAIRS.
41.0.11.•••••-

I love it, I love it, and who shall dare
To chide me for loving my barber shop chair?
We've treasured them long, and now they are ours
If true squatter sovereignty gives any powers.
We're bound by a thousand fond ties to our seats,
For there ev'ry day the Fernandis Club meets.
Would you learn the spell?—'tis there we talk scandal,
And matters of state we can easily handle.
In freshman days I lingered near
Those hallowed seats with listening ear;
And warm were the words which the club would give
In teaching the way a man best should live.
There heard I the freshest of things from society,
With a dash of the green room to give them variety.
0 nothing I now recall ever compares
With the wisdom I learned from those barber shop chairs.
I sat in my chair for many a day
When all thought of study had vanished away;
When youth was most rosy and nature most mild,
The first of the month—when Dame Fortune had smiled—
In poker I still was ahead of the game,
In tossing up nickels my luck was the same;
For then I was king, and the world was my own,
And I ruled it right well from my barber shop throne.
'Tis past. 'tis past, and hard is the rule
Which leaves in the shop not even a stool.
'Tis there that we gossiped, and there we felt sure
From the faculty's onslaughts we were most secure.
Let Us rise in a body, insist on our right
Of having our chairs or of having a tight;
For I love it, I love it, and I cannot tear
My soul from the seat of my barber shop chair.
'03.

LAST FRIDAY NIGHT'S CONCERT.

t

HE annual concert of our Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs at Lehmann's
Hall on February 27 was a great success. That the Baltimore public
appreciate a '`good thing" when they see it was proved by the large audience which greeted them, and which enthusiastically applauded the various
selections.
The concert hall was tastefully decorated with Southern smilax; the stage,
banked with flowers and surmounted with the University motto in huge letters,
produced a very pleasing effect. Placed at intervals on the walls were the different class flags, and the athletic banners,—reminders of 'varsity successes.
The large number of patronesses, outside friends of the University, as well
as the wives of the members of the faculty, contributed much to the success of
the evening.
The program opened with the University Ode. Then came some rollicking
songs, and marches by the banjo and mandolin clubs. Selections by the quartette appeared twice on the program, and each time the members, T. H. Coffin,
F. J. Hall, F. R. Ford and P. K. Gilman. received a warm reception from the
audience. The Glee Club was greatly appreciated in the 1902 and 1903 medleys, arranged by W. B Carver.
The selection "Violets" was particularly well rendered by the mandolin
club, as was also the "Baltimore Centennial," in which "Dixie" was played as
a clarionet solo, while the mandolins and violins played "Maryland. My Maryland." The program ended with a new Hopkins song. "The Toast Song," of
which the words and music were composed by R. S. Lanier, our ex-editor-inchief.
The Mandolin Club is deserving of much praise. It surpasses last year's
club in volume and unity of tone, and the members show that they have been
well trained under their leader, J. W. Bryan. The Glee Club, under the able
leadership of W. B. Carver, did very satisfactory work, and is to be commended. The Banjo Club, with C. A. Marshall as leader, was excellent. They
played with the same spirit and dash that characterized last year's club.
Altogether the concert was successful from every point of view. The management and players are to be congratulated on their efforts. Most encouraging of all is the fact that the concert was a financial success, insuring the clubs
a
good Easter trip.

Y. M. C. A NOTES.

O

N Saturday evening, February 21, eight Hopkins men joined with about
fifty other men of Baltimore colleges in a Northfield supper at the invi •
tation of the Baltimore Mt. Hermon Club. The Mt. Hermon Club is
the organization of the alumni of Mr Moody's school, just across the river
from Northfield, Mass. The object of the gathering was to arouse interest in
the summer student conference at Northfield next summer, June 26 to July 5.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

11

This object tvas accomplished by six brief talks on the various sides of Northfield life and by much fun and reminiscing during the supper. There is always a strong feeling of friendship and enthusiasm among a party of men who
have been to Northfield.
The State convention for Delaware, Maryland and District of Columbia, in
Baltimore, March 6, 7 and 8, bids fair to be of interest to college men. The
Saturday sessions will be of special interest, and the afternoon, with possibly
the morning session, will be held in Levering Hall. Mr. A. B. Williams, Jr.,
secretary of college work of the east, will have charge of the student conference.
He comes to us from a visit to the U. of P. and other institutions in the east,
and Hopkins should give him a good welcome. St. John's, Western Maryland
and other colleges expect to send large delegations. Hazlehurst, J. T. Smith,
Jr., Sandrock, Hildt and Lloyd are a committee looking after the entertainment
of some of these men. It is desired that as many Hopkins men as possible
will come to the Saturday afternoon session.
Mr. Williams will remain a few days after the convention to meet the Hop •
kins men here and at the Medical School, and will lead the meeting Tuesday,
March 10, at 5 o'clock. He is a Yale man of considerable experience in college
association work.
The attendance at morning prayers has fallen off lately. It is hoped that
Christian men who have the nine o'clock period on will avail themselves of
G.
this little opportunity for quiet worship.

HEN we consider the fact that by this time next month the first game of
the lacrosse season will have been played, it may readily be seen that
no little work must he done between now and then. Harvard, it is
said, has been playing in two inches of snow for the past two weeks and Lehigh
and Swarthmore have both heen doing outdoor work despite the weather. No
matter how great an advantage the cage may be, the practice within its walls
must nece,sarily be on a small scale and it is very important. that the squad
should be gotten out as soon as possible in order to give the men an idea of the
positions and distances to be covered on a field of regulation size.
Ex-Captain Schmeisser and Coach Abercrombie were much pleased with
practice
in the cage last Saturday. They both laid particular stress upon
the
the fact that the schedule this year is unquestionably the hardest ever arrayed
by the management, and urged the candidates to stop all smoking and drinking
preparatory to signing the training pledge which will probably be required next
week. The remarkable work done by the 'Varsity twelve last year was mainly
due to the fine condition of the men throughout the season. In a game requiring such a great amount of wind and endurance too much stress cannot be laid
upon the necessity of conscientious training. The absence of a training table
make each player responsible in a large measure for his own condition. The
trust should be rigidly lived up to by every man who has any chance to make
the team.

HOPKINS AT GEORGETOWN GAMES.
UDGING from the list of Hopkins men who are to take part in the Georgetown games on Saturday night, we should carry off at least a few medals. Captain R. C. Hoffman has been putting the squad through all
kinds of preparatory stunts since the B. A. C. games. and should the handicapping be reasonable, we may expect to get a liberal share of the honors.
The men who are to wear our cobors will be taken from the following: Dashes—
Freeze, Sladen, Bond, •Pessagno, Tootle, LeCron, Knight, Helmholz, Super.
Middle Distance—England, Tootle, LeCron, C L. Stone, Boyce, Morse, Goode•
now, Super, Freese, Captain R. C. Hoffman. Distance—Aedewell, Porter,
Morse, England. Shot Put— H. B. Stone, Lawson. Jumps—Taylor, Pessagno, Knight. Hurdles—Freese,•Heltuholz. Relay Race—England, Capt. Hoffman, Freeze, C. L. Stone, Sladen, Tootle; Morse, Redewell. Somewhat to Hopkins' disappointment, the relay race will be run with Villa Nova College. The
latter institutions always turns out a, well trained team, but Captain Hoffman
was greatly in hope that a contest could be arranged either with the Carlisle
Indians or the United States Naval Academy. The Indian management very
frankly wrote Manag r Dulaney that the team was not in sufficiently good condition to run against Hopkins, while the Navy has not developed a relay team
this season.
The games w ill be both handicap and scratch, and altogether Hopkins ex
pects a reasonab y fair chance in all the events.
For several days past Manager Dulany and Physical Director McDermott
have been tryi ng to secure special rates for the occasion. Even if they do not
succeed, the usual Saturday fare is opzii to all, and there is no reason why
a bunch of rooters should not go with the team. The games will be held in
Convention Hall, at 8 o'clock.
• In m ost of the events Hopkins will have our old friends, the Maryland and
the Balti more Athletic Clubs to down. The Boys' Latin School and Marston's
have also entered teams.

ott. It is this: The Maryland Athletic Club has very kindly offered the
ohns Hopkins track and field team the use of the Maryland Oval for training

Hopkins and M. A. C. have been on very intimate terms during the winter, and the present courtesy is simply a token of the good feeling which it is
hoped will continue to exist between Baltimore's most prominent institution of

If circumstances are favorable, Hopkins will hold her annual indoor games
at the Fifth Regiment Armory on March 28. No definite arrangements have as

BASE BALL ENTHUSIASTS.
ASE BALL affairs began to assume a truly formidable aspect last Saturday afternoon, when 15 candidates showed up for the first regular practice of the season; and from now on they will report every Tuesday and
Thursday, as well as on Saturday, for a little warming-up exercise. With the
first game only about two weeks off, it will be necessary for the men to attend
strictly to business during the short time they can be together. As regards
practice, the base ball team is singularly unfortunate, in that the candidates are
so scattered that it is almost impossible to get them all together for practice,
even when grounds can be procured for the purpose. The team is further
handicapped by the very limited amount of time that the "medicos" can spare.
It is scarcely possible at this time to give with any great degree of accuracy the candidates for the several positions; therefore, too great faith must not
be put in the following remarks Captain Whipple will again be seen doing
business at the old stand in the box, with Ricksher, Wright, Crozier, and
Pitcher as candidates for the same position. Constantine, who will give up
first base for a place behind the hat, may be succeeded by Ingraham or Goldman. Hand or Sladen will probably do the honors at second, with Marine or
Nelson at third. Short will again be ably filled by Moore. For the outfield,
'the selection may be made from Wright, Marshall, Hand or Goldman. The
above leaves Meloy, Campbell, and Straughn unaccounted for, as they cannot
yet be definitely located.
The candidates who reported Saturday were: Whipple, Constantine, Ricksher, Ingraham, Meloy, Wright, Marine, Moore, Hand, Crozier, Sladen, Campbell, Goldman, Straughn and Pitcher. After the practice, a short, informal
business meeting was held in the Trophy Room. The present prospects of the
team are very bright, and all look forward to a successful season.

SOLILOQUY OF A BANQUETER.

Ir

OW ! How that water sizzled going down! I am not going to make any
excuses for myself. But really now, did I fall or was I pushed?
Anyway, the water-gon'
drove off and left me. As an idiot, I deserve
the can of salmon, the box of mustard plasters, and any other old prize that is
yearning for a nice unintelligent owner. Ouch! I didn't know that my head
was so big. I wonder if some one sneaked up behind me and hit me with a
brick? Pocketbook? That went long ago. I am vaguely conscious that I
have put my name to more bills of lading—for booze---than I ever signed to
examination papers. On my'honor, that's a fact.
How did it start? Don't ask me. How do I know? I imagine that every
one started in the afternoon, just to test their capacity. By evening we could
just manage to see the.dozen oysters spinning about on our plates. I don't
think that I was worse than anyone else. I know I wasn't; I didn't sing.
Yes, I did too. Something foolish about "Did the Goat Eat the Spinach off
Sister Susie's Hat?" It must have been pathetic; the man next to me wept on
my shoulder and gurgled something about losing one dearer than a sister.
I am trying to find the man who said that I hit a waiter on the eye with a
roll. and compromised for a dollar. I can't remember it. The only evidence
that I have that it might be so is in the fact that I am minus the dollar. That's
nothing; I'm minus several of them. I must have been awful reckless. I
found a champagne cork in my pocket. I hope some one gave it to me for a
souvenir; I hope I didn't have the hardihood to do it myself. Four Bones! A
week's board! Sixteen times to the Auditorium! Thirty two—lemonades!
Who'd have thought it?
It's me to economize. Never tell me that wine is a mocker. I know it
already. It is the only original tanglefoot. It took three of us to navigate. I
had to hold the other two up. Them hold ME up! I guess not. I was the
main support of that Complete Combination of Curiosities. Although there
was no sleet on the pavement, I am well aware of the fact that there were distinct seismic sensations at different times. I wanted to take those two Indians
'home. They wanted' to take ME home. We compromised; none of us went
home. We saw the cold gray dawn break, but we were broke first; we saw the
stars go out, but we had gone out first; we saw the moon grow pale, but we
were paler than she. Today you can't hand me too many pledges to sign.
Good bye, I'm off to get some ice. for my head.

EXCHANGES.

The Princeton " er'' calls attention to the following dainty bit from the
Wellesley Magazine":
"The nightgown was very light. Millicent lifted it with surprise. Her
own felt quite different as she took them out of the bureau drawer—stiff and
smooth in their white starchedness. This was a slim, soft thing. Her own
were of unbleached muslin, plenty long, with a yoke, and a square collar, buttoning neatly at the throat. A little thrill of doubt ran over her as she slipped
into this bit of softness. It fell around her ankles lingeringly; her throat rose
out of it with a sweet sense of freedom; the soft embroidery caressed her wrists.
She drew her breath with a little doubting sense of immodesty and tingled anew
as she felt the cool folds She put out the light and stood in the shadow of a
moonbeam, trembling in this keen. new consciousness of her own body. She
could feel every curve of it under the thin, clinging thing. She had a strange,
sweet sympathy with her own warm flesh, and an apprehension of beautiful
things, known to her before only through her eyes, seemed diffused through her
whole body."

A WINTER IDYLL.

The moon was softly shining
In the dark blue firmament,
And the stars were brightly twinkling,
As in gleaming wonderment;
And the wind was softly sighing
As they glided o'er the ice,
While she whispered to him gently,
"Oh, say! Jimmie—ain't this nice?"
—Cobrnilria Jester.

MARCH 5, 1903.

No. 10.

COMMEMORATION DAY CELEBRATION.
OHNS HOPKINS celebrated the twenty-seventh anniversary of her foundation on Monday, February 23, by the customary commemoration exercises
with which her birthdays have been regularly observed in the past. On
several recent occasions these exercises have been marked by announcements
of such importance as to excite interest wherever men are who concern themselves with the progress of American education. First came the University's •
application for aid from the State of Maryland; then various statements concerning the movements set going to restore her to the stabler position of the
fore-time, movements gradually centering in that final one by which the endowment fund of $1,000,000 was completed last summer, and last of all, the opening
of "The Promised Land" on upper Charles street. The optimists who
expected President Remsen to acknowledge the gift of funds ample to cover the
Homewood acres with stately buildings in which the great fame of Hopkins
shall grow greater, as a proper culmination to the double quick of earlier events,
were not fully gratified. President Remsen's own remarks indicated that he
himself knew of many such.
"A gentleman stopped me on .the street the other day and declared he
would^be sorely disappointed unless I announced that we have enough money
in hand to build at. Homewood," he said. "I could only smile then, and I can
do nothing better now."
"If you ask,'what, then are you going to do with Homewood?' I should
reply, that we shall for the present study it—learn how it will best serve our
Purpose, and none but the ,best advice will suit us. You know already that
the president of our Board, Mr. R. Brent Keyser, has provided funds to enable
us to secure expert advice. I may also tell you that the trustees, as many as
can leave, will go this spring upon a tour of observation to learn what other
universities can teach us for the development of the Homewood land. They
will visit Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Columbia, Cornell, Virginia and other
places, too, perhaps."
The memory of Henry A. Rowland, whose researches in physics, contributing a great measure to the renown of Johns Hopkins, will endure of their
own merit, is assured of fuller perpetuation in the University itself by a gift •
announced at the exercises. A student of the late Professor Rowland has
offered to buy a complete library covering the field of spectroscopy, which was
..

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

one of the special branches of science which Dr. Rowland cultivated for many
years with great success. "The Rowland Memorial Library of Spectroscopy"
will he the name of the new collection, and Mrs. Rowland has contributed to it
all of the Professor's own books on that subject.
By the gift of $25,000 from Dr. and Mrs. Christian H. Herter, of New York,
the University will be able to invite some eminent professor of that branch of
science to lecture in Baltimore each year hereafter.
The commemoration exercises were those which are generally familiar to
all who have ever been students at Johns Hopkins. The Academic procession,
this year under the Chief Marshalship of Dr. Harry L Wilson, entered the
auditorium to a march rendered by an orchestra under the direction of Prof. W.
Edward Heimendahl of the Peabody Conservatory. President Remsen headed
the line in company with the orator of the day, President Edwin A. Alderman,
of Tulane University, President Emeritus D. C. Gilman following with the
chaplain, Dr. Arthur Chilton Powell. The guests and several academic bodies
coming after in the usual order.
The President, the President Emeritus, and the Orator, occupied the center
of the stage, Dr. Remsen seated in the President Chair presented two years ago
by the Harvard Club of Maryland.
In introducing the speaker of the day, President Remsen said: "A year
ago a company in Music Hall, at a banquet memorable in the annals of Johns
Hopkins, weary, perhaps, with the lapse of hours, suddenly woke up. It was
near midnight, but an electric shock had passed—a speech generated it. It
could not last long, however, because the next day was Sunday. When we
came to prepare for this occasion it occurred to us that we could do no better
than invite the man who made that speech a year ago to continue it here this
morning. It gives me great pleasure, accordingly, to present to you President
Alderman of Tulane University, New Orleans"
President Alderman's address was devoted for the most part to a retrospective and prospective view of the South. In the most glowing manner he
spoke of the splendid and noble attributes of the old South, not, however,
neglecting to acknowledge those defects and vices which have disappeared
before the forces of modern civilization. Referring to the present time, Dr.
Alderman told of the great change that has now progressed so far, the passing
of the traditional and agricultural South into the active, modern industrial community. Believing that the South has before it a great future, along with the
rest of the nation, President Alderman feels that the great need of the South is
the placing of its educational system upon an equal footing with that which
exists in the most advanced and prosperous parts of the land.
The degree of Doctor of Philosophy was conferred upon Mr. Frederick
Hutton Getman, University of Virginia; Mr. Benjamin Leroy Miller, A. B.,
University of Kansas, 1897; Mr. Henry Nevi11 Sanders, A. B., Trinity University, Toronto, 1894, and Mr. Daniel Naylor Shoemaker, S. B., Earlham College, 1895.

the Carnegie Institute.
The growing interest in the exercises caused such a demand for tickets that
many persons were unable to obtain them and even a number of those holding
tickets were unable to gain admittance into the assembly room. Referring to
the necessity of having a larger auditorium in which to hold the Commemo
ration Day exercises, Dr. Remsen said: "I do not know whether or not this

in it at this moment; but notwithstanding this we have been obliged to turn
away a great many of those we should like to see here. This could not be
avoided, but we will try to devise means by which we may have all our friends
with us on future occasions of this sort."

THE ALUMNI BANQUET.

t

H E annual banquet of the Alumni Association held at the Carrollton Hotel
on the night of the 23rd, made a fitting close for the day's celebration.
At a short business meeting before the banquet, the gentlemen who had
been nominated by the Executive Committee, as announced in the last issue of
the “liftws-LETTHR," were elected to hold office for the ensuing year. The
company then proceeded to the banquet hall, where an excellent dinner was
thoroughly enjoyed. At the conclusion, toast-master Dr. W. T. Sedgwick, the
retiring president of the association, made a short address of welcome to the
Alumni, in which he dwelt strongly on the national character of the University,
which he said was the pioneer in the work of nationalizing the educational field
of the country. He also spoke of the vast amount of useful work which the
University could do if only the requisite funds were provided. Those who responded to toasts were:—
Dr. Gilman. introduced as the "Master of Johns Hopkins," who
spoke of the national influence exerted by the Univetsity, and mentioned many
of its graduates who have attained distinction in the various paths of life, es-,
pecially in the province of higher education.
President Remsen, who emphasized the fact that the true purpose of a university was to train men for scientific investigation. He said that, as the de
mand for investigators in this country far exceeded the supply, he believed such
institutions as the Carnegie and Rockefellet Institutes to be detrimental; for
they tend to draw away from the universities men fitted to train these investigators
Dr. Alderman, who depicted the noble grander of the "scholar-patriot."
Mr. Theodore Marburg, who spoke on behalf of the trustees.
Professor H. H. Donaldson, Ph. D., 1885, dean of graduate school of the
University of Chicago.

ECENTLY a great scare was given the men who make the barber shop their
official headquarters when not attending classes. Owing to an order
which emanated from some unknown source all the chairs were removed
from the room. Fortunately for those tired mortals who settle all the great
questions of the day, while seated in the chairs which have been provided for
Walter's patrons, on the following day the chairs were returned, and the dove
of peace settled once more above the doorway. Had the chairs not been returned, although the NEWS.LETTER would have objected, yet it would have
been honest enough to acknowledge that there was wisdom in the order which
emanated from the aforesaid unseen source. We cannot deny that the barber
shop is most conducive to that most catching of college diseases—loafing. We
cannot deny that as a result of the above mentioned disease the place at times
does not present the most tidy appearance. We cannot deny that at times the
atmosphere is dense with .the smoke of the vile weed. We cannot deny that
Walter some times gets so interested in a story or a colloquy that he inadvertently chips off a corner of the face of some trusting, unwary patron. In all
this there is danger. But on the other hand there is one thing which, to our
mind, overbalances these drawbacks and turns the scales in favor of providing
seats for those men who prefer idleness to industry, and the freedom of a barber
shop debate to the august solemnness of the house or the senate. It is this

g

THE NEWS LETTER.

7

College life at best is but for a shOrt season. Soon the men who now are engaged
in looking at life from what we may call a theoretical view point will be looking
at the same problem from its practical side, and in mmory they will live over
again their college days They will not think of the days spent in the laboratory as much EIS they will of the days spent in chasing the pigskin over the
field, they will not think of the dry lectures as much as the wet banquets, and
they will not think of the papers they read in class as much as they will of the
hours stolen from study to spend in the midst of that bohemian organization
known as the Fernandig Club. In a word, it is not the memory of the duh
faithfully done which brings the same pleasure in after years as the mcmory of
those moments of relaxation when we .pause in the harness to take breath before continuing the steady pull up the hill. We have no historic "fence" upon
which the upper classmen may perch, we have no historic steps upon which the
men may sing college ballads, we have nothing but Walter's barbershop. So
let us try and preserve that intact. And may every man, when his day comes
to leave, carry away with him no darker view of college life than that he obtains in Walter's tonsorial parlor!
N an article in the last issue of the NEWS—LETTER under the heading of
"Base Ball for 1903," it was stated that the "statement may now be accepted as authoritative that Hopkins will have a base ball team this
season." This was erroneous, and the NEWS LETTER regrets that it was given
to the public in a manner which seemed to vouch for the authenticity of the report. As long ago as the holidays the Athletic Board declared that there
would be no representative team this season. It is true that a team composed
of Hopkins men will play during the season; but they have not the sanction ot
the Athletic Board, nor are they at liberty to use Hopkins' name as has been
done in several newspaper articles and in the last issue of the NEWS-LETTER.
The base ball enthusiasts are in the main men from the Medical School, and if
the team takes the field as an independent, self-supporting organization it might
well be called the Johns Hopkins Medical School Base Ball Team, as at Yale
there is a Yale Law School Base Ball Team. This would relieve the men from
being under the authority and discipline of the Athletic Association. Although
the team will be composed of University men it must be understood that the
Athletic Association offers no guarantee for the fulfillment of their pledges

PROSPECTS FOR THE COMING DEBATE.
S the time draws nearer for the inter-class debate which will probably he
held on March 2 1 st, interest on the part of those who are contesting for
the various places on the teams is perceptibly increasing. Both Juniors
and Seniors are buckling down to work. and are sifting out all the material they
can find on the subject of the debate. Practice is held every day under the
direction of Dr. Lee and Mr. Burgess of the Baltimore School of Oratory, at
which times the echoes of McCoy Hall are rudely awakened by the impassioned
eloquence of aspiring orators. Indeed, every indication seems to show that
both sides will put up a stiff fight on the.night of the twenty-first.
The cbntest has, however, narrowed down to six men on each side from
which the speakers and alternates of the two teams will be chosen.
For the Seniors, these are Plaggemeyer, Blum, Strayer, Tootle, Addison,
Glocker.
For the Juniors, they are Licking, Humrichouse, Foster, Rosenheim,
Stollenwerck, Crozier.
It has also been decided to have adviEers as in former years. The advisers
for the Seniors will probably be Custis, Ammen, Parsons, and Hopper. Those
for the Juniors wiil be chosen from Loyd, Emig, Geiger, Wallis, and Opie
The Freshmen who will contest on the night of the debate for the medal
offered by Dr. Lee, will be selected from Strauglin, Boyce, Ziegler and Goldman.
After the inter-class contest, comes the debate with North Carolina. The
southern university has, so report says, put us down as one of their regular
annular scalps, but we want to disappoint them, and wipe out the defeat of
last year by carrying victory into the heart of the Carolinas. To do this, every
man must come out and work. It is probable that the speakers who will represent Hopkins will be selected from the inter-class debating teams, but every
undergraduate is eligible, and, if he only makes manifest his latent ability, will
receive due consideration. But those who do not possess the gift of eloquence
are not absolved. Valuable assistance can be rendered by a squad of enthusiastic workers who will help to write speeches,, run down material, and, above
all, criticise the arguments of the speakers, instead of waiting, as usual, for
defeat to he announced before letting forth a stored.up flood of criticism.

OUR BARBER SHOP CHAIRS.
41.0.11.•••••-

I love it, I love it, and who shall dare
To chide me for loving my barber shop chair?
We've treasured them long, and now they are ours
If true squatter sovereignty gives any powers.
We're bound by a thousand fond ties to our seats,
For there ev'ry day the Fernandis Club meets.
Would you learn the spell?—'tis there we talk scandal,
And matters of state we can easily handle.
In freshman days I lingered near
Those hallowed seats with listening ear;
And warm were the words which the club would give
In teaching the way a man best should live.
There heard I the freshest of things from society,
With a dash of the green room to give them variety.
0 nothing I now recall ever compares
With the wisdom I learned from those barber shop chairs.
I sat in my chair for many a day
When all thought of study had vanished away;
When youth was most rosy and nature most mild,
The first of the month—when Dame Fortune had smiled—
In poker I still was ahead of the game,
In tossing up nickels my luck was the same;
For then I was king, and the world was my own,
And I ruled it right well from my barber shop throne.
'Tis past. 'tis past, and hard is the rule
Which leaves in the shop not even a stool.
'Tis there that we gossiped, and there we felt sure
From the faculty's onslaughts we were most secure.
Let Us rise in a body, insist on our right
Of having our chairs or of having a tight;
For I love it, I love it, and I cannot tear
My soul from the seat of my barber shop chair.

LAST FRIDAY NIGHT'S CONCERT.

t

HE annual concert of our Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs at Lehmann's
Hall on February 27 was a great success. That the Baltimore public
appreciate a '`good thing" when they see it was proved by the large audience which greeted them, and which enthusiastically applauded the various
selections.
The concert hall was tastefully decorated with Southern smilax; the stage,
banked with flowers and surmounted with the University motto in huge letters,
produced a very pleasing effect. Placed at intervals on the walls were the different class flags, and the athletic banners,—reminders of 'varsity successes.
The large number of patronesses, outside friends of the University, as well
as the wives of the members of the faculty, contributed much to the success of
the evening.
The program opened with the University Ode. Then came some rollicking
songs, and marches by the banjo and mandolin clubs. Selections by the quartette appeared twice on the program, and each time the members, T. H. Coffin,
F. J. Hall, F. R. Ford and P. K. Gilman. received a warm reception from the
audience. The Glee Club was greatly appreciated in the 1902 and 1903 medleys, arranged by W. B Carver.
The selection "Violets" was particularly well rendered by the mandolin
club, as was also the "Baltimore Centennial," in which "Dixie" was played as
a clarionet solo, while the mandolins and violins played "Maryland. My Maryland." The program ended with a new Hopkins song. "The Toast Song," of
which the words and music were composed by R. S. Lanier, our ex-editor-inchief.
The Mandolin Club is deserving of much praise. It surpasses last year's
club in volume and unity of tone, and the members show that they have been
well trained under their leader, J. W. Bryan. The Glee Club, under the able
leadership of W. B. Carver, did very satisfactory work, and is to be commended. The Banjo Club, with C. A. Marshall as leader, was excellent. They
played with the same spirit and dash that characterized last year's club.
Altogether the concert was successful from every point of view. The management and players are to be congratulated on their efforts. Most encouraging of all is the fact that the concert was a financial success, insuring the clubs
a
good Easter trip.

N Saturday evening, February 21, eight Hopkins men joined with about
fifty other men of Baltimore colleges in a Northfield supper at the invi •
tation of the Baltimore Mt. Hermon Club. The Mt. Hermon Club is
the organization of the alumni of Mr Moody's school, just across the river
from Northfield, Mass. The object of the gathering was to arouse interest in
the summer student conference at Northfield next summer, June 26 to July 5.

This object tvas accomplished by six brief talks on the various sides of Northfield life and by much fun and reminiscing during the supper. There is always a strong feeling of friendship and enthusiasm among a party of men who
have been to Northfield.
The State convention for Delaware, Maryland and District of Columbia, in
Baltimore, March 6, 7 and 8, bids fair to be of interest to college men. The
Saturday sessions will be of special interest, and the afternoon, with possibly
the morning session, will be held in Levering Hall. Mr. A. B. Williams, Jr.,
secretary of college work of the east, will have charge of the student conference.
He comes to us from a visit to the U. of P. and other institutions in the east,
and Hopkins should give him a good welcome. St. John's, Western Maryland
and other colleges expect to send large delegations. Hazlehurst, J. T. Smith,
Jr., Sandrock, Hildt and Lloyd are a committee looking after the entertainment
of some of these men. It is desired that as many Hopkins men as possible
will come to the Saturday afternoon session.
Mr. Williams will remain a few days after the convention to meet the Hop •
kins men here and at the Medical School, and will lead the meeting Tuesday,
March 10, at 5 o'clock. He is a Yale man of considerable experience in college
association work.

HEN we consider the fact that by this time next month the first game of
the lacrosse season will have been played, it may readily be seen that
no little work must he done between now and then. Harvard, it is
said, has been playing in two inches of snow for the past two weeks and Lehigh
and Swarthmore have both heen doing outdoor work despite the weather. No
matter how great an advantage the cage may be, the practice within its walls
must nece,sarily be on a small scale and it is very important. that the squad
should be gotten out as soon as possible in order to give the men an idea of the
positions and distances to be covered on a field of regulation size.
Ex-Captain Schmeisser and Coach Abercrombie were much pleased with
practice
in the cage last Saturday. They both laid particular stress upon
the
the fact that the schedule this year is unquestionably the hardest ever arrayed
by the management, and urged the candidates to stop all smoking and drinking
preparatory to signing the training pledge which will probably be required next
week. The remarkable work done by the 'Varsity twelve last year was mainly
due to the fine condition of the men throughout the season. In a game requiring such a great amount of wind and endurance too much stress cannot be laid
upon the necessity of conscientious training. The absence of a training table
make each player responsible in a large measure for his own condition. The
trust should be rigidly lived up to by every man who has any chance to make
the team.
Regarding the vacancies, there will be at least three attack and one defense positions to be filled by new men. The candidates who are at all promising have a good opportunity to figure in one or two, if not all the games. Just

HOPKINS AT GEORGETOWN GAMES.
UDGING from the list of Hopkins men who are to take part in the Georgetown games on Saturday night, we should carry off at least a few medals. Captain R. C. Hoffman has been putting the squad through all
kinds of preparatory stunts since the B. A. C. games. and should the handicapping be reasonable, we may expect to get a liberal share of the honors.
The men who are to wear our cobors will be taken from the following: Dashes—
Freeze, Sladen, Bond, •Pessagno, Tootle, LeCron, Knight, Helmholz, Super.
Middle Distance—England, Tootle, LeCron, C L. Stone, Boyce, Morse, Goode•
now, Super, Freese, Captain R. C. Hoffman. Distance—Aedewell, Porter,
Morse, England. Shot Put— H. B. Stone, Lawson. Jumps—Taylor, Pessagno, Knight. Hurdles—Freese,•Heltuholz. Relay Race—England, Capt. Hoffman, Freeze, C. L. Stone, Sladen, Tootle; Morse, Redewell. Somewhat to Hopkins' disappointment, the relay race will be run with Villa Nova College. The
latter institutions always turns out a, well trained team, but Captain Hoffman
was greatly in hope that a contest could be arranged either with the Carlisle
Indians or the United States Naval Academy. The Indian management very
frankly wrote Manag r Dulaney that the team was not in sufficiently good condition to run against Hopkins, while the Navy has not developed a relay team
this season.
The games w ill be both handicap and scratch, and altogether Hopkins ex
pects a reasonab y fair chance in all the events.
For several days past Manager Dulany and Physical Director McDermott
have been tryi ng to secure special rates for the occasion. Even if they do not
succeed, the usual Saturday fare is opzii to all, and there is no reason why
a bunch of rooters should not go with the team. The games will be held in
Convention Hall, at 8 o'clock.
• In m ost of the events Hopkins will have our old friends, the Maryland and
the Balti more Athletic Clubs to down. The Boys' Latin School and Marston's
have also entered teams.

A piece of exceptional good fortune, which is not generally known to the
Director MackderStiident body, was announced a few days ago by Physical
ott. It is this: The Maryland Athletic Club has very kindly offered the
ohns Hopkins track and field team the use of the Maryland Oval for training
purposes during the coming season.
This is certainly a piece of genuine good luck, for the Oval is not only
much nearer town than Electric Park, but it is circled by a first-class quartermile cinder track. Besides this the grounds are strictly private and contain a
spacious club house equipped with,several shower baths.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Hopkins and M. A. C. have been on very intimate terms during the winter, and the present courtesy is simply a token of the good feeling which it is
hoped will continue to exist between Baltimore's most prominent institution of
learning and her leading athletic organization.

If circumstances are favorable, Hopkins will hold her annual indoor games
at the Fifth Regiment Armory on March 28. No definite arrangements have as
yet been made.
BASE BALL ENTHUSIASTS.
ASE BALL affairs began to assume a truly formidable aspect last Saturday afternoon, when 15 candidates showed up for the first regular practice of the season; and from now on they will report every Tuesday and
Thursday, as well as on Saturday, for a little warming-up exercise. With the
first game only about two weeks off, it will be necessary for the men to attend
strictly to business during the short time they can be together. As regards
practice, the base ball team is singularly unfortunate, in that the candidates are
so scattered that it is almost impossible to get them all together for practice,
even when grounds can be procured for the purpose. The team is further
handicapped by the very limited amount of time that the "medicos" can spare.
It is scarcely possible at this time to give with any great degree of accuracy the candidates for the several positions; therefore, too great faith must not
be put in the following remarks Captain Whipple will again be seen doing
business at the old stand in the box, with Ricksher, Wright, Crozier, and
Pitcher as candidates for the same position. Constantine, who will give up
first base for a place behind the hat, may be succeeded by Ingraham or Goldman. Hand or Sladen will probably do the honors at second, with Marine or
Nelson at third. Short will again be ably filled by Moore. For the outfield,
'the selection may be made from Wright, Marshall, Hand or Goldman. The
above leaves Meloy, Campbell, and Straughn unaccounted for, as they cannot
yet be definitely located.
The candidates who reported Saturday were: Whipple, Constantine, Ricksher, Ingraham, Meloy, Wright, Marine, Moore, Hand, Crozier, Sladen, Campbell, Goldman, Straughn and Pitcher. After the practice, a short, informal
business meeting was held in the Trophy Room. The present prospects of the
team are very bright, and all look forward to a successful season.

SOLILOQUY OF A BANQUETER.

Ir

OW ! How that water sizzled going down! I am not going to make any
excuses for myself. But really now, did I fall or was I pushed?
Anyway, the water-gon'
drove off and left me. As an idiot, I deserve
the can of salmon, the box of mustard plasters, and any other old prize that is
yearning for a nice unintelligent owner. Ouch! I didn't know that my head
was so big. I wonder if some one sneaked up behind me and hit me with a
brick? Pocketbook? That went long ago. I am vaguely conscious that I
have put my name to more bills of lading—for booze---than I ever signed to
examination papers. On my'honor, that's a fact.
How did it start? Don't ask me. How do I know? I imagine that every
one started in the afternoon, just to test their capacity. By evening we could
just manage to see the.dozen oysters spinning about on our plates. I don't
think that I was worse than anyone else. I know I wasn't; I didn't sing.
Yes, I did too. Something foolish about "Did the Goat Eat the Spinach off
Sister Susie's Hat?" It must have been pathetic; the man next to me wept on
my shoulder and gurgled something about losing one dearer than a sister.
I am trying to find the man who said that I hit a waiter on the eye with a
roll. and compromised for a dollar. I can't remember it. The only evidence
that I have that it might be so is in the fact that I am minus the dollar. That's
nothing; I'm minus several of them. I must have been awful reckless. I
found a champagne cork in my pocket. I hope some one gave it to me for a
souvenir; I hope I didn't have the hardihood to do it myself. Four Bones! A
week's board! Sixteen times to the Auditorium! Thirty two—lemonades!
Who'd have thought it?
It's me to economize. Never tell me that wine is a mocker. I know it
already. It is the only original tanglefoot. It took three of us to navigate. I
had to hold the other two up. Them hold ME up! I guess not. I was the
main support of that Complete Combination of Curiosities. Although there
was no sleet on the pavement, I am well aware of the fact that there were distinct seismic sensations at different times. I wanted to take those two Indians
'home. They wanted' to take ME home. We compromised; none of us went
home. We saw the cold gray dawn break, but we were broke first; we saw the
stars go out, but we had gone out first; we saw the moon grow pale, but we
were paler than she. Today you can't hand me too many pledges to sign.
Good bye, I'm off to get some ice. for my head.

The Princeton " er'' calls attention to the following dainty bit from the
Wellesley Magazine":
"The nightgown was very light. Millicent lifted it with surprise. Her
own felt quite different as she took them out of the bureau drawer—stiff and
smooth in their white starchedness. This was a slim, soft thing. Her own
were of unbleached muslin, plenty long, with a yoke, and a square collar, buttoning neatly at the throat. A little thrill of doubt ran over her as she slipped
into this bit of softness. It fell around her ankles lingeringly; her throat rose
out of it with a sweet sense of freedom; the soft embroidery caressed her wrists.
She drew her breath with a little doubting sense of immodesty and tingled anew
as she felt the cool folds She put out the light and stood in the shadow of a
moonbeam, trembling in this keen. new consciousness of her own body. She
could feel every curve of it under the thin, clinging thing. She had a strange,
sweet sympathy with her own warm flesh, and an apprehension of beautiful
things, known to her before only through her eyes, seemed diffused through her
whole body."

A WINTER IDYLL.

The moon was softly shining
In the dark blue firmament,
And the stars were brightly twinkling,
As in gleaming wonderment;
And the wind was softly sighing
As they glided o'er the ice,
While she whispered to him gently,
"Oh, say! Jimmie—ain't this nice?"
—Cobrnilria Jester.
